Legal_Issue: Was the Board's rejection of the Roma families' refugee claims based on reasonable assessment of state protection and credibility?
Governing_Law: Transparent, intelligible analysis of actual state protection available at the present time
Application_Facts: Two Roma families fled Hungary due to persecution and sought refugee status in Canada but were rejected
Court_Ruling: Decision overturned, new hearing ordered with separate consideration for each family
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of effective state protection for Roma
Assessment_Factor: Availability of state protection in Hungary
Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable findings made by the Board
Evidence_Used: Evidence showed Hungary fails to protect its Roma citizens effectively
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section requiring transparent and intelligible analysis of state protection
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to ethnic origin
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation of systemic discrimination and violence against Roma in Hungary
Governing_Rule: A refugee claim must be assessed based on current, real state protection, not future promises
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for redetermination by a different Board Member
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution if returned to Hungary
Cause_Description: Two Roma families fled Hungary due to persecution and sought refugee status in Canada but were rejected
Evidence_Handling: Inadequate consideration of evidence regarding state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections of IRPA related to fair and reasonable refugee determination
Evidence_Issues: Failure to properly assess available country condition evidence
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient analysis of effectiveness of Hungarian state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to provide transparent and intelligible reasons for rejecting claims
